I would suggest picking one of the unique Google hits (URLs) that is a 
short address and in your best guess likely to be reachable by a 
short-number-of-clicks from the seed. Call this the target URL.

Then, verify that in a regular web browser you can click from the seed, 
through one or more other interim hop URLs that stay on the same 
hostname, to reach the target URL.

In this way, you're following the same steps as the crawler.

Then look carefully at all the interim hop URLs, and ensure each is 
individually followable by the crawler according to its rules.

For example, if the seed is URL A, and the target is URL D, and you have 
to click to URL B then URL C to go from A->B->C->D, pay close attention 
to B and C.

Perhaps B is in your Heritrix crawl, but C is not. Then focus your 
attention on what's different about C. Is C on another hostname? Was C 
blocked by a robots.txt rule? Was it only followable due to something in 
page B (like Javascript- or Flash-heavy content) that might be hard for 
the crawler to follow?

Usually this makes evident exactly how the default scope should be 
broadened to include what you intuitively think the 'site' should be. 
(This process also works in reverse, to deduce the first 'hop' where the 
crawler gets something you didn't expect.)

Now, it's not necessarily the case that it's even possible to reach D 
from A while staying on the same site. Many well-organized sites ensure 
this, but sometimes only external links lead to 'islands' of deeper 
pages... and Google's global view is more likely to discover those.

Hope this helps.

- Gordon @ IA
